questiontext.text:
A survey with 50 persons was conducted to analyze the design of an advertising campaign. Each respondent was asked to evaluate the overall impression of the advertisement on an eleven-point scale from 0 (bad) to 10 (good). The evaluations are summarized separately with respect to type of occupation of the respondents in the following figure.

To analyze the influence of occupation on the evaluation of the advertisement an analysis of variance was performed:

  Res.Df    RSS Df Sum of Sq     F     Pr(>F)
1     49 20.283                              
2     46 13.336  3     6.947 7.987 0.00021666

Which of the following statements are correct?

generalfeedback.text:
In order to be able to answer the questions the fraction of explained variance has to be determined. The residual sum of squares when using only a single overall mean value (\(\mathit{RSS}_0\)) as well as the residual sum of squares when allowing different mean values given occupation (\(\mathit{RSS}_1\)) are required. Both are given in the RSS column of the ANOVA table. The fraction of explained variance is given by \(1 - \mathit{RSS}_1/\mathit{RSS}_0 = 1 - 13.336/20.283 = 0.343\).

The statements above can now be evaluated as right or wrong.

  1. False. The fraction of explained variance is \(0.343\) and hence not smaller than 0.17.
  2. False. An ANOVA always tests the null hypothesis, that all mean values are equal against the alternative hypothesis that they are different.
  3. True. The \(p\) value is \(0.000217\) and hence significant. It can be shown that the evaluations differ with respect to the occupation of the respondents.
  4. True. The fraction of explained variance is \(0.343\) and hence larger than 0.21.
  5. False. The test statistic is \(F = 7.987\) and hence not smaller than \(4.8\).

answer.text: The fraction of explained variance is smaller than \(17\)%.

feedback.text: False. The fraction of explained variance is \(0.343\) and hence not smaller than 0.17.

answer.text: A one-sided alternative was tested for the mean values.

feedback.text: False. An ANOVA always tests the null hypothesis, that all mean values are equal against the alternative hypothesis that they are different.

answer.text: It can be shown that the evaluation of the respondents depends on their occupation. (Significance level \(5\%\))

feedback.text: True. The \(p\) value is \(0.000217\) and hence significant. It can be shown that the evaluations differ with respect to the occupation of the respondents.

answer.text: The fraction of explained variance is larger than \(21\)%.

feedback.text: True. The fraction of explained variance is \(0.343\) and hence larger than 0.21.

answer.text: The test statistic is smaller than \(4.8\).

feedback.text: False. The test statistic is \(F = 7.987\) and hence not smaller than \(4.8\).

questiontext.text:
For the 43 observations of the variable x in the data file boxhist.csv draw a histogram, a boxplot and a stripchart. Based on the graphics, answer the following questions or check the correct statements, respectively. (Comment: The tolerance for numeric answers is \(\pm0.4\), the true/false statements are either about correct or clearly wrong.)

  1. {1:MULTICHOICE:=The distribution is unimodal.~The distribution is not unimodal.}
  2. {1:MULTICHOICE:The distribution is symmetric.~=The distribution is right-skewed.~The distribution is left-skewed.}
  3. {1:MULTICHOICE:=The boxplot shows outliers.~The boxplot shows no outliers.}
  4. A quarter of the observations is smaller than which value? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.27:0.4}
  5. A quarter of the observations is greater than which value? {1:NUMERICAL:=1.11:0.4}
  6. Half of the observations are greater than which value? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.38:0.4}

generalfeedback.text:
1. True / False
  2. False / True / False
  3. True / False
  4. 0.27
  5. 1.11
  6. 0.38

questiontext.text: In the following figure the distributions of a variable given by two samples (A and B) are represented by parallel boxplots. Which of the following statements are correct? (Comment: The statements are either about correct or clearly wrong.)

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. Distribution B has on average higher values than distribution A.
  2. False. There are observations which deviate more than 1.5 times the interquartile range from the median.
  3. True. The interquartile range in sample A is clearly bigger than in B.
  4. True. The skewness of both distributions is similar, both are right-skewed.
  5. False. Distribution A is right-skewed.

answer.text: The location of both distributions is about the same.

feedback.text: False. Distribution B has on average higher values than distribution A.
False. There are observations which deviate more than 1.5 times the interquartile range from the median.

answer.text: The spread in sample A is clearly bigger than in B.

feedback.text: True. The interquartile range in sample A is clearly bigger than in B.

answer.text: The skewness of both samples is similar.

feedback.text: True. The skewness of both distributions is similar, both are right-skewed.
False. Distribution A is right-skewed.

questiontext.text: Which of the following cities are the capital of the corresponding country?

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. The capital of New Zealand is Wellington.
  2. True. Astana is the capital of Kazakhstan.
  3. False. The capital of Turkey is Ankara.
  4. False. The de facto capital of Switzerland is Bern.
  5. True. Tokyo is the capital of Japan.

feedback.text: False. The capital of New Zealand is Wellington.
True. Astana is the capital of Kazakhstan.
False. The capital of Turkey is Ankara.
False. The de facto capital of Switzerland is Bern.
True. Tokyo is the capital of Japan.

questiontext.text:
For the matrix \[\begin{aligned} A &= \left( \begin{array}{rrrr} 16 & -12 & -16 & 16 \\ -12 & 34 & 27 & 3 \\ -16 & 27 & 34 & -7 \\ 16 & 3 & -7 & 41 \end{array} \right).\end{aligned}\] compute the matrix \(L = (\ell_{ij})_{1 \leq i,j \leq 4}\) from the Cholesky decomposition \(A = L L^\top\).

Which of the following statements are true?

generalfeedback.text:
The decomposition yields \[\begin{aligned} L &= \left( \begin{array}{rrrr} 4 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ -3 & 5 & 0 & 0 \\ -4 & 3 & 3 & 0 \\ 4 & 3 & 0 & 4 \end{array} \right)\end{aligned}\] and hence:

  1. True. \(\ell_{33} = 3\)
  2. False. \(\ell_{32} = 3 \ngtr 3\)
  3. True. \(\ell_{41} = 4\)
  4. True. \(\ell_{11} = 4\)
  5. False. \(\ell_{21} = -3 \nless -3\)

feedback.text: True. \(\ell_{33} = 3\)
False. \(\ell_{32} = 3 \ngtr 3\)
True. \(\ell_{41} = 4\)
True. \(\ell_{11} = 4\)
False. \(\ell_{21} = -3 \nless -3\)

questiontext.text:
The daily expenses of summer tourists in Vienna are analyzed. A survey with \(106\) tourists is conducted. This shows that the tourists spend on average \(133\) EUR. The sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(154.2\).

Determine a \(95\%\) confidence interval for the average daily expenses (in EUR) of a tourist.

generalfeedback.text: The \(95\%\) confidence interval for the average expenses \(\mu\) is given by: \[\begin{aligned} & & \left[\bar{y} \, - \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}, \; \bar{y} \, + \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}\right] \\ & = & \left[ 133 \, - \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{154.2}{106}}, \; 133 \, + \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{154.2}{106}}\right] \\ & = & \left[130.636, \, 135.364\right].\end{aligned}\]

questiontext.text:
The daily expenses of summer tourists in Vienna are analyzed. A survey with \(132\) tourists is conducted. This shows that the tourists spend on average \(119.1\) EUR. The sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(135.7\).

Determine a \(95\%\) confidence interval for the average daily expenses (in EUR) of a tourist.

  1. What is the lower confidence bound? {1:NUMERICAL:=117.113:0.01}
  2. What is the upper confidence bound? {1:NUMERICAL:=121.087:0.01}

generalfeedback.text:
The \(95\%\) confidence interval for the average expenses \(\mu\) is given by: \[\begin{aligned} & & \left[\bar{y} \, - \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}, \; \bar{y} \, + \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}\right] \\ & = & \left[ 119.1 \, - \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{135.7}{132}}, \; 119.1 \, + \, 1.96\sqrt{\frac{135.7}{132}}\right] \\ & = & \left[117.113, \, 121.087\right].\end{aligned}\]

  1. The lower confidence bound is \(117.113\).
  2. The upper confidence bound is \(121.087\).

questiontext.text:
It is suspected that a supplier systematically underfills 5 l canisters of detergent. The filled volumes are assumed to be normally distributed. A small sample of \(10\) canisters is measured exactly. This shows that the canisters contain on average \(4978.6\) ml. The sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(2045.3\).

Determine a \(99\%\) confidence interval for the average content of a canister (in ml).

  1. What is the lower confidence bound? {1:NUMERICAL:=4932.123:0.1~%50%4941.762:0.1#Approximately normal instead of exact t solution.}
  2. What is the upper confidence bound? {1:NUMERICAL:=5025.077:0.1~%50%5015.438:0.1#Approximately normal instead of exact t solution.}

generalfeedback.text:
The \(99\%\) confidence interval for the average content \(\mu\) in ml is given by: \[\begin{aligned} & & \left[\bar{y} \, - \, t_{n-1;0.995}\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}, \; \bar{y} \, + \, t_{n-1;0.995}\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}\right] \\ & = & \left[ 4978.6 \, - \, 3.2498\sqrt{\frac{2045.3}{10}}, \; 4978.6 \, + \, 3.2498\sqrt{\frac{2045.3}{10}}\right] \\ & = & \left[4932.123, \, 5025.077\right].\end{aligned}\]

  1. The lower confidence bound is \(4932.123\).
  2. The upper confidence bound is \(5025.077\).

questiontext.text: What is the three-letter country code (ISO 3166-1 alpha-3) for Brunei?

generalfeedback.text: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 code for Brunei is BRN.

questiontext.text: On 2013-05-03 one Euro (€) was buying 1.3109 US Dollars ($) and 0.8431 British Pounds (£). At Frankfurter Börse around noon adidas AG was the largest winner compared with the day before with a price of € 84.8492 per share. If you buy 77 shares, how much are they worth in €?

generalfeedback.text: The worth in € is the number of shares \(\times\) stock price \(\times\) exchange rate, i.e., \(77 \times 84.8492 \times 1 \approx 6533.388\).

questiontext.text: What is the derivative of \(f(x) = x^{8} e^{3.6x}\), evaluated at \(x = 0.76\)?

generalfeedback.text: Using the product rule for \(f(x) = g(x) \cdot h(x)\), where \(g(x) := x^{8}\) and \(h(x) := e^{3.6x}\), we obtain \[\begin{aligned} f'(x) & = & [g(x) \cdot h(x)]' = g'(x) \cdot h(x) + g(x) \cdot h'(x) \\ & = & 8 x^{8 - 1} \cdot e^{3.6x} + x^{8} \cdot e^{3.6x} \cdot 3.6 \\ & = & e^{3.6x} \cdot(8 x^7 + 3.6 x^{8}) \\ & = & e^{3.6x} \cdot x^7 \cdot (8 + 3.6x).\end{aligned}\] Evaluated at \(x = 0.76\), the answer is \[e^{3.6\cdot 0.76} \cdot 0.76^7 \cdot (8 + 3.6\cdot 0.76) = 24.253105.\] Thus, rounded to two digits we have \(f'(0.76) = 24.25\).

questiontext.text: What is the derivative of \(f(x) = x^{2} e^{3.9x}\), evaluated at \(x = 0.65\)?

generalfeedback.text:
Using the product rule for \(f(x) = g(x) \cdot h(x)\), where \(g(x) := x^{2}\) and \(h(x) := e^{3.9x}\), we obtain \[\begin{aligned} f'(x) & = & [g(x) \cdot h(x)]' = g'(x) \cdot h(x) + g(x) \cdot h'(x) \\ & = & 2 x^{2 - 1} \cdot e^{3.9x} + x^{2} \cdot e^{3.9x} \cdot 3.9 \\ & = & e^{3.9x} \cdot(2 x^1 + 3.9 x^{2}) \\ & = & e^{3.9x} \cdot x^1 \cdot (2 + 3.9x).\end{aligned}\] Evaluated at \(x = 0.65\), the answer is \[e^{3.9\cdot 0.65} \cdot 0.65^1 \cdot (2 + 3.9\cdot 0.65) = 37.190084.\] Thus, rounded to two digits we have \(f'(0.65) = 37.19\).

  1. False
  2. False
  3. True
  4. False
  5. False

False
True
False

questiontext.text: What is the distance between the two points \(p = (2, 4)\) and \(q = (5, 5)\) in a Cartesian coordinate system?

generalfeedback.text:
The distance \(d\) of \(p\) and \(q\) is given by \(d^2 = (p_1 - q_1)^2 + (p_2 - q_2)^2\) (Pythagorean formula).

Hence \(d = \sqrt{(p_1 - q_1)^2 + (p_2 - q_2)^2} = \sqrt{(2 - 5)^2 + (4 - 5)^2} = 3.162\).

questiontext.text:
Given two points \(p = (1, 3)\) and \(q = (3, 5)\) in a Cartesian coordinate system:

  1. What is the Manhattan distance \(d_1(p, q)\)? {1:NUMERICAL:=4:0.01}
  2. What is the Euclidean distance \(d_2(p, q)\)? {1:NUMERICAL:=2.828:0.01}
  3. What is the maximum distance \(d_\infty(p, q)\)? {1:NUMERICAL:=2:0.01}

generalfeedback.text:
The distances are visualized below in green (\(d_1\)), red (\(d_2\)), and blue (\(d_\infty\)).

  1. \(d_1(p, q) = \sum_i |p_i - q_i| = |1 - 3| + |3 - 5| = 4\).
  2. \(d_2(p, q) = \sqrt{\sum_i (p_i - q_i)^2} = \sqrt{(1 - 3)^2 + (3 - 5)^2} = 2.828\).
  3. \(d_\infty(p, q) = \max_i |p_i - q_i| = \max(|1 - 3|, |3 - 5|) = 2\).

questiontext.text: What is the distance between the two points \(p = (2, 3)\) and \(q = (4, 2)\) in a Cartesian coordinate system?

generalfeedback.text:
The distance \(d\) of \(p\) and \(q\) is given by \(d^2 = (p_1 - q_1)^2 + (p_2 - q_2)^2\) (Pythagorean formula).

Hence \(d = \sqrt{(p_1 - q_1)^2 + (p_2 - q_2)^2} = \sqrt{(2 - 4)^2 + (3 - 2)^2} = 2.236\).

  1. False
  2. False
  3. False
  4. True
  5. False

feedback.text: False
False
False
True
False

questiontext.text:
Consider the following regression results:

Call:
lm(formula = y ~ x, data = d)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-1.86125 -0.53222 -0.07195  0.57294  2.78071 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) -0.08941    0.11695  -0.764    0.448
x           -0.91396    0.11132  -8.210 1.91e-11

Residual standard error: 0.9244 on 61 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.525, Adjusted R-squared:  0.5172 
F-statistic: 67.41 on 1 and 61 DF,  p-value: 1.912e-11

Describe how the response y depends on the regressor x.

generalfeedback.text:
The presented results describe a linear regression.

The mean of the response y decreases with increasing x.

If x increases by \(1\) unit then a change of y by about \(-0.91\) units can be expected.

Also, the effect of x is significant at the \(5\) percent level.

questiontext.text:
An industry-leading company seeks a qualified candidate for a management position. A management consultancy carries out an assessment center which concludes in making a positive or negative recommendation for each candidate: From previous assessments they know that of those candidates that are actually eligible for the position (event \(E\)) \(63\%\) get a positive recommendation (event \(R\)). However, out of those candidates that are not eligible \(73\%\) get a negative recommendation. Overall, they know that only \(11\%\) of all job applicants are actually eligible.

What is the corresponding fourfold table of the joint probabilities? (Specify all entries in percent.)

  1. \(P(E \cap R)\) {1:NUMERICAL:=6.93:0.05}
  2. \(P(\overline{E} \cap R)\) {1:NUMERICAL:=24.03:0.05}
  3. \(P(E \cap \overline{R})\) {1:NUMERICAL:=4.07:0.05}
  4. \(P(\overline{E} \cap \overline{R})\) {1:NUMERICAL:=64.97:0.05}

generalfeedback.text:
Using the information from the text, we can directly calculate the following joint probabilities: \[\begin{aligned} P(E \cap R) & = & P(R | E) \cdot P(E) = 0.63 \cdot 0.11 = 0.0693 = 6.93\%\\ P(\overline{E} \cap \overline{R}) & = & P(\overline{R} | \overline{E}) \cdot P(\overline{E}) = 0.73 \cdot 0.89 = 0.6497 = 64.97\%.\end{aligned}\] The remaining probabilities can then be found by calculating sums and differences in the fourfold table:

 \(R\)   \(\overline{R}\)  sum
 \(E\)   6.93   4.07   11.00 
 \(\overline{E}\)   24.03   64.97   89.00 
sum  30.96   69.04   100.00 
  1. \(P(E \cap R) = 6.93\%\)
  2. \(P(\overline{E} \cap R) = 24.03\%\)
  3. \(P(E \cap \overline{R}) = 4.07\%\)
  4. \(P(\overline{E} \cap \overline{R}) = 64.97\%\)

questiontext.text:
An industry-leading company seeks a qualified candidate for a management position. A management consultancy carries out an assessment center which concludes in making a positive or negative recommendation for each candidate: From previous assessments they know that of those candidates that are actually eligible for the position (event \(E\)) \(77\%\) get a positive recommendation (event \(R\)). However, out of those candidates that are not eligible \(67\%\) get a negative recommendation. Overall, they know that only \(14\%\) of all job applicants are actually eligible.

What is the corresponding fourfold table of the joint probabilities? (Specify all entries in percent.)

 \(R\)   \(\overline{R}\)  sum
 \(E\)    {1:NUMERICAL:=10.78:0.05~%0%10:0}%    {1:NUMERICAL:=3.22:0.05~%0%10:0}%    {1:NUMERICAL:=14:0.05~%0%10:0}% 
 \(\overline{E}\)    {1:NUMERICAL:=28.38:0.05~%0%10:0}%    {1:NUMERICAL:=57.62:0.05~%0%10:0}%    {1:NUMERICAL:=86:0.05~%0%10:0}% 
sum   {1:NUMERICAL:=39.16:0.05~%0%10:0}%    {1:NUMERICAL:=60.84:0.05~%0%10:0}%    {1:NUMERICAL:=100:0.05~%0%10:0}%

generalfeedback.text:
Using the information from the text, we can directly calculate the following joint probabilities: \[\begin{aligned} P(E \cap R) & = & P(R | E) \cdot P(E) = 0.77 \cdot 0.14 = 0.1078 = 10.78\%\\ P(\overline{E} \cap \overline{R}) & = & P(\overline{R} | \overline{E}) \cdot P(\overline{E}) = 0.67 \cdot 0.86 = 0.5762 = 57.62\%.\end{aligned}\] The remaining probabilities can then be found by calculating sums and differences in the fourfold table:

 \(R\)   \(\overline{R}\)  sum
 \(E\)   10.78   3.22   14.00 
 \(\overline{E}\)   28.38   57.62   86.00 
sum  39.16   60.84   100.00 
  1. \(P(E \cap R) = 10.78\%\)
  2. \(P(\overline{E} \cap R) = 28.38\%\)
  3. \(P(E \cap \overline{R}) = 3.22\%\)
  4. \(P(\overline{E} \cap \overline{R}) = 57.62\%\)
  5. \(P(R) = 39.16\%\)
  6. \(P(\overline{R}) = 60.84\%\)
  7. \(P(E) = 14.00\%\)
  8. \(P(\overline{E}) = 86.00\%\)
  9. \(P(\Omega) = 100.00\%\)

questiontext.text:
Given the following information:

\(+\) \(+\) = \(597\)
\(+\) \(+\) = \(119\)
\(+\) \(+\) = \(1035\)

Compute:

\(+\) \(+\) = \(\text{?}\)

generalfeedback.text:
The information provided can be interpreted as the price for three fruit baskets with different combinations of the three fruits. This corresponds to a system of linear equations where the price of the three fruits is the vector of unknowns \(x\):

\(x_1 =\) \(x_2 =\) \(x_3 =\)

The system of linear equations is then: \[\begin{aligned} \left( \begin{array}{rrr} 0 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \end{array} \right) \cdot \left( \begin{array}{r} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{array} \right) & = & \left( \begin{array}{r} 597 \\ 119 \\ 1035 \end{array} \right)\end{aligned}\] This can be solved using any solution algorithm, e.g., elimination: \[x_1 = 33, \, x_2 = 53, \, x_3 = 491.\] Based on the three prices for the different fruits it is straightforward to compute the total price of the fourth fruit basket via:

\(+\) \(+\) \(=\)
\(x_1\) \(+\) \(x_2\) \(+\) \(x_3\) \(=\)
\(33\) \(+\) \(53\) \(+\) \(491\) \(=\) \(577\).

questiontext.text:
Given the following information:

\(+\) \(+\) = \(497\)
\(+\) \(+\) = \(272\)
\(+\) \(+\) = \(505\)

Compute:

\(+\) \(+\) = \(\text{?}\)

generalfeedback.text:
The information provided can be interpreted as the price for three fruit baskets with different combinations of the three fruits. This corresponds to a system of linear equations where the price of the three fruits is the vector of unknowns \(x\):

\(x_1 =\) \(x_2 =\) \(x_3 =\)

The system of linear equations is then: \[\begin{aligned} \left( \begin{array}{rrr} 2 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 1 \end{array} \right) \cdot \left( \begin{array}{r} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{array} \right) & = & \left( \begin{array}{r} 497 \\ 272 \\ 505 \end{array} \right)\end{aligned}\] This can be solved using any solution algorithm, e.g., elimination: \[x_1 = 88, \, x_2 = 92, \, x_3 = 321.\] Based on the three prices for the different fruits it is straightforward to compute the total price of the fourth fruit basket via:

\(+\) \(+\) \(=\)
\(x_1\) \(+\) \(x_2\) \(+\) \(x_3\) \(=\)
\(88\) \(+\) \(92\) \(+\) \(321\) \(=\) \(501\).

questiontext.text: What is the name of the R function for extracting the estimated covariance matrix from a fitted (generalized) linear model object?

generalfeedback.text: vcov is the R function for extracting the estimated covariance matrix from a fitted (generalized) linear model object. See ?vcov for the corresponding manual page.

questiontext.text: Under the assumptions of the Gauss-Markov theorem the errors of a linear regression model need to be:

generalfeedback.text:
Under the assumptions of the Gauss-Markov theorem the errors of a linear regression model need to be uncorrelated, homoscedastic, and with mean zero.

  1. True. The errors need to be homoscedastic with finite variance.
  2. False. No distribution assumption is needed.
  3. False. No distribution assumption is needed.
  4. False. Independence is not assumed, only lack of correlation.
  5. True. The errors need to be uncorrelated.

feedback.text: True. The errors need to be homoscedastic with finite variance.
False. No distribution assumption is needed.
False. No distribution assumption is needed.
False. Independence is not assumed, only lack of correlation.
True. The errors need to be uncorrelated.

questiontext.text: Compute the Hessian of the function \[\begin{aligned} f(x_1, x_2) = 9 x_1^{2} + 4 x_1 x_2 + 9 x_2^{2}\end{aligned}\] at \((x_1, x_2) = (4, -1)\). What is the value of the upper left element?

generalfeedback.text:
The first-order partial derivatives are \[\begin{aligned} f'_1(x_1, x_2) &=& 18 x_1 + 4 x_2 \\ f'_2(x_1, x_2) &=& 4 x_1 + 18 x_2\end{aligned}\] and the second-order partial derivatives are \[\begin{aligned} f''_{11}(x_1, x_2) &=& 18\\ f''_{12}(x_1, x_2) &=& 4\\ f''_{21}(x_1, x_2) &=& 4\\ f''_{22}(x_1, x_2) &=& 18\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the Hessian is \[\begin{aligned} f''(x_1, x_2) = \left( \begin{array}{rr} 18 & 4 \\ 4 & 18 \end{array} \right)\end{aligned}\] independent of \(x_1\) and \(x_2\). Thus, the upper left element is: \(f''_{11}(4, -1) = 18\).

  1. False
  2. True
  3. False
  4. False
  5. False

feedback.text: False
True
False
False
False

questiontext.text:
A firm has the following production function: \[F(K,L)= K L^{}.\] The price for one unit of capital is \(p_K = 4\) and the price for one unit of labor is \(p_L = 14\). Minimize the costs of the firm considering its production function and given a target production output of 460 units.

How high are in this case the minimal costs?

generalfeedback.text:
Step 1: Formulating the minimization problem. \[\begin{aligned} \min_{K,L} C(K,L) &=& p_K K + p_L L\\ &=& 4 K + 14 L\\ \mbox{subject to:} && F(K,L) = Q \\ && K L^{} = 460 \end{aligned}\]

Step 2: Lagrange function. \[\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(K, L, \lambda) &=& C(K, L)-\lambda (F(K, L) - Q) \\ &=& 4 K + 14 L - \lambda (K L^{} -460)\end{aligned}\]

Step 3: First order conditions. \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial {\mathcal {L}}}{\partial K} & = & 4 - \lambda L^{} = 0\\ \frac{\partial {\mathcal {L}}}{\partial L} & = & 14 - {1} \lambda K L^{1-1} = 0 \\ \frac{\partial {\mathcal {L}}}{\partial \lambda} & = & -(K L^{}-460) = 0\end{aligned}\]

Step 4: Solve the system of equations for \(K\), \(L\), and \(\lambda\).

Equating Equations (1) and (2) after solving for \(\lambda\) gives: \[\begin{aligned} \frac{4}{L^{}} & = & \frac{14}{{1} K L^{1-1}}\\ K & = & \frac{14}{1 \cdot 4} \cdot L^{1 - (1 -1)}\\ K & = & \frac{14}{4} \cdot L\end{aligned}\]

Substituting this in the optimization constraint gives: \[\begin{aligned} K L^{} & = & 460\\ \left(\frac{14}{4}\cdot L \right) L^{} & = & 460\\ \frac{14}{4} L^{2} & = & 460\\ L & = & \left(\frac{4}{14} \cdot 460\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} = 11.46423008~\approx~11.46\\ K & = & \frac{14}{4} \cdot L = 40.12480528~\approx~40.12\end{aligned}\]

The minimal costs can be obtained by substituting the optimal factor combination in the objective function: \[\begin{aligned} C(K, L) & = & 4 K + 14 L\\ & = & 160.499221 + 160.499221 \\ & = & 320.998442 \approx 321.00 \end{aligned}\] Given the target output, the minimal costs are \(321.00\).

questiontext.text:
Using the data provided in regression.csv estimate a linear regression of y on x and answer the following questions.

  1. {1:MULTICHOICE:x and y are not significantly correlated~y increases significantly with x~=y decreases significantly with x}
  2. Estimated slope with respect to x: {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.641:0.01}

generalfeedback.text:
To replicate the analysis in R:

## data
d <- read.csv("regression.csv")
## regression
m <- lm(y ~ x, data = d)
summary(m)
## visualization
plot(y ~ x, data = d)
abline(m)

questiontext.text:
Consider the following gates coding logical operators:

A B C

Which of these gates belongs to the following logical truth table?

generalfeedback.text:
The truth table codes the logical or operator.

The gates displayed code the following logical operators: A = nor, B = or, C = nand.

Hence, the truth table corresponds to: B.

  1. False
  2. True
  3. False
  4. False

feedback.text: False
True
False
False

questiontext.text:
For 65 firms the number of employees \(X\) and the amount of expenses for continuing education \(Y\) (in EUR) were recorded. The statistical summary of the data set is given by:

Variable \(X\) Variable \(Y\)
Mean 57 238
Variance 102 2275

The correlation between \(X\) and \(Y\) is equal to 0.81.

Estimate the expected amount of money spent for continuing education by a firm with 65 employees using least squares regression.

generalfeedback.text:
First, the regression line \(y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_i + \varepsilon_i\) is determined. The regression coefficients are given by: \[\begin{aligned} && \hat \beta_1 = r \cdot \frac{s_y}{s_x} = 0.81 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{2275}{102}} = 3.82539, \\ && \hat \beta_0 = \bar y - \hat \beta_1 \cdot \bar x = 238 - 3.82539 \cdot 57 = 19.95281.\end{aligned}\]

The estimated amount of money spent by a firm with 65 employees is then given by: \[\begin{aligned} \hat y = 19.95281 + 3.82539 \cdot 65 = 268.603.\end{aligned}\]

questiontext.text:
In a small city the satisfaction with the local public transportation is evaluated. One question of interest is whether inhabitants of the city center are more satisfied with public transportation compared to those living in the suburbs.

A survey with 250 respondents gave the following contingency table:

           Location
Evaluation  city center suburbs
  very good          17      13
  good               47      24
  bad                26      65
  very bad           10      48

The following table of percentages was constructed:

           Location
Evaluation  city center suburbs    
  very good        56.7        43.3
  good             66.2        33.8
  bad              28.6        71.4
  very bad         17.2        82.8

Which of the following statements are correct?

generalfeedback.text:
In the percentage table, the row sums are about 100 (except for possible rounding errors). Hence, the table provides row percentages, i.e., conditional proportions for location given satisfaction level.

  1. False. The column sums do not give 100.
  2. False. The total sums do not give 100.
  3. True. This evaluation gives row percentages.
  4. False. This is an interpretation of total percentages, but the table gives row percentages.
  5. False. This is an interpretation of column percentages, but the table gives row percentages.

answer.text: The percentage table gives the satisfaction distribution for each location type.

feedback.text: False. The column sums do not give 100.

answer.text: The percentage table contains total percentages.

feedback.text: False. The total sums do not give 100.

answer.text: The percentage table can be easily constructed from the original contingency table: percentages are calculated for each row.

feedback.text: True. This evaluation gives row percentages.

answer.text: The value in row 4 and column 1 in the percentage table indicates: 17.2 percent of the respondents live in the city center and evaluated the public tranportation as very bad.

feedback.text: False. This is an interpretation of total percentages, but the table gives row percentages.

answer.text: The value in row 2 and column 1 in the percentage table indicates: 66.2 percent of the respondents in the city center evaluated the public transportation as good.

feedback.text: False. This is an interpretation of column percentages, but the table gives row percentages.

questiontext.text: What does the following logo stand for?

generalfeedback.text:
The logo stands for the R system for statistical computing and graphics (http://www.R-project.org/).

  1. False. R is an open-source project, not a company.
  2. False. Although R is (also) a letter in the alphabet, this is not what the logo represents.
  3. False. The R project does not sell anything.
  4. True. R is a programming language.
  5. False. R is not a search engine.

feedback.text: False. R is an open-source project, not a company.
False. Although R is (also) a letter in the alphabet, this is not what the logo represents.
False. The R project does not sell anything.
True. R is a programming language.
False. R is not a search engine.

questiontext.text: The following figure shows a scatterplot. Which of the following statements are correct?

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. The regression line at \(X=-49.9\) implies a value of about \(Y = 61\).
  2. False. Only a slightly positive association between the variables is observable in the scatterplot. This implies a correlation coefficient with an absolute value smaller than \(0.8\).
  3. False. The slope of the regression line is given by \(r \cdot s_y/s_x\) and hence not about equal to \(1\).
  4. False. The standard deviation of \(X\) is about equal to \(1\) and is therefore smaller than \(6\).
  5. True. The mean of \(Y\) is about equal to \(60\) and hence is larger than \(30\).

answer.text: For \(X = -49.9\), \(Y\) can be expected to be about 21 .

feedback.text: False. The regression line at \(X=-49.9\) implies a value of about \(Y = 61\).

answer.text: The absolute value of the correlation coefficient is at least \(0.8\).

feedback.text: False. Only a slightly positive association between the variables is observable in the scatterplot. This implies a correlation coefficient with an absolute value smaller than \(0.8\).

answer.text: The slope of the regression line is about \(1\).

feedback.text: False. The slope of the regression line is given by \(r \cdot s_y/s_x\) and hence not about equal to \(1\).

answer.text: The standard deviation of \(X\) is at least \(6\).

feedback.text: False. The standard deviation of \(X\) is about equal to \(1\) and is therefore smaller than \(6\).

answer.text: The mean of \(Y\) is at least \(30\).

feedback.text: True. The mean of \(Y\) is about equal to \(60\) and hence is larger than \(30\).

questiontext.text: What is the seat of the federal authorities in Switzerland (i.e., the de facto capital)?

generalfeedback.text:
There is no de jure capital but the de facto capital and seat of the federal authorities is Bern.

  1. False.
  2. False.
  3. False.
  4. True.
  5. False.

feedback.text: False.
False.
False.
True.
False.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements about Switzerland is correct?

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. There is no de jure capital but the de facto capital of Switzerland is Bern.
  2. True. The official languages are: German, French, Italian, Romansh.
  3. False. The currency is the Swiss Franc (CHF).
  4. False. Switzerland is part of the Schengen Area but not the EU.
  5. True. The establishment of the Swiss Confederation is traditionally dated to August 1, 1291.

answer.text: Zurich is the capital of Switzerland.

feedback.text: False. There is no de jure capital but the de facto capital of Switzerland is Bern.

answer.text: Italian is an official language in Switzerland.

feedback.text: True. The official languages are: German, French, Italian, Romansh.

answer.text: The currency in Switzerland is the Euro.

feedback.text: False. The currency is the Swiss Franc (CHF).

answer.text: Switzerland is part of the European Union (EU).

feedback.text: False. Switzerland is part of the Schengen Area but not the EU.

answer.text: The Swiss national holiday is August 1.

feedback.text: True. The establishment of the Swiss Confederation is traditionally dated to August 1, 1291.

questiontext.text:
Measuring the protein concentration in raw milk you obtain the following sample of \(n=17\) observations. Test the two-sided hypothesis \(H_0: \mu = 3.5\) given that the sample measurements follow a normal distribution.

 [1] 4.29 3.96 4.31 5.09 4.58 4.68 4.10 4.17 4.57 4.83 3.83 4.57 4.08 4.52 3.63 4.41 3.54

Fill in the gaps below:

  1. Mean {1:NUMERICAL:=4.304:0.1}
  2. Variance {1:NUMERICAL:=0.175:0.001~%50%0.175:0.1#Rounding error; correct answer: 0.175}
  3. Test statistic {1:NUMERICAL:=7.916:0.1}
  4. Lower “critical” value {1:NUMERICAL:=-2.921:0.1}
  5. Upper “critical” value {1:NUMERICAL:=2.921:0.1}
  6. {1:MULTICHOICE_V:Keep \(H_0\)~=Reject \(H_0\)}

A machine fills milk into \(250\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 250\). A sample of \(170\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(236.7\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(176.81\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text: The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{236.7 - 250}{\sqrt{\frac{176.81}{170}}} = -13.041.\end{aligned}\] The absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(13.041\).

questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(250\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 250\). A sample of \(230\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(231.5\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(130.93\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text:
The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{231.5 - 250}{\sqrt{\frac{130.93}{230}}} = -24.52.\end{aligned}\] The \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(-24.520\).

  1. False
  2. False
  3. True
  4. False
  5. False

feedback.text: False
False
True
False
False

questiontext.text:
The waiting time (in minutes) at the cashier of two supermarket chains with different cashier systems is compared. The following statistical test was performed:

    Two Sample t-test

data:  Waiting by Supermarket
t = -1.3439, df = 135, p-value = 0.1812
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -1.6935040  0.3231159
sample estimates:
 mean in group Sparag mean in group Consumo 
             5.288424              5.973618

Which of the following statements are correct? (Significance level \(5\%\))

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. The absolute value of the test statistic is equal to 1.344.
  2. False. The test aims at showing that the difference of means is unequal to \(0\).
  3. True. The \(p\) value is equal to \(0.181\).
  4. False. The test result is not significant (\(p \ge 0.05\)).
  5. False. The test result ist not significant (\(p \ge 0.05\)).

answer.text: The absolute value of the test statistic is larger than 1.96.

feedback.text: False. The absolute value of the test statistic is equal to 1.344.
False. The test aims at showing that the difference of means is unequal to \(0\).

answer.text: The \(p\) value is larger than \(0.05\).

feedback.text: True. The \(p\) value is equal to \(0.181\).

answer.text: The test shows that the waiting time is longer at Sparag than at Consumo.

feedback.text: False. The test result is not significant (\(p \ge 0.05\)).

answer.text: The test shows that the waiting time is shorter at Sparag than at Consumo.

feedback.text: False. The test result ist not significant (\(p \ge 0.05\)).
